data.text: Leasons Learned in Your First Bikepacking Adventure?

In your first bike packing adventure, what lessons did you learn? I am already thinking that I may be packing too much for my first adventure. (like an ultra light chair and small table, comes to around 2 kilos in total), and also went down the pannier route, but thought what the hell, you only live once. I can fine tune the setup at a later date, once I have got a handle on the whole process. Prefer more room(panniers) even if it's not all utilised, than struggling to fit everything into a restricted storage after potentially a stressfull night :)
One important lesson, it‚Äôs not how far you travel, it‚Äôs how much your enjoy the journey. Hey, if a table and chair make your trip more enjoyable then go with it üëçüèª
data.author: Bikepacking & Cycle Touring UK

data.text: Yea, those are my thoughts exactly, but I will never be an ultralight bike packer(mainly due to me being 130 kilos, although hopefully if I can do these regularly plus normal in the week local cycle rides, this will come down), so if I can bring some creature comforts that make the whole adventure more enjoyable, why not? :)
data.author: Ray Breen

data.text: Yea, i am used to doing road riding, where the main goal is to get to your destination as quickly as possible, with the odd stop on the way. Bike packing is pretty much the opposite, it's much more casual(relatively) and about the sights and just enjoying being out and about. I've got to remember to mentally change my gears :)
data.author: Ray Breen

data.text: I took too many clothes and too much food. Didn't take any kit I didn't need. Trail shot water filter is brilliant
data.author: Christian Bird

data.text: Yea, i have a uv c water filter on its way (from kickstarter) which will do the trick if i need to fill up at streams or other water sources.
data.author: Ray Breen

data.text: After your first trip you will know what you need and don't, enjoy the experience..
data.author: Debs Phil Walton Smith

data.text: It's nice to take comforts but for me personally a table and chair is overkill. If you're happy with it though cool üëç I just use a small closed foam cell mat to sit on. What I learnt from my first trip though was to evenly distribute the weight. A few times I accelerated and almost pulled a wheely because the back of the bike was way too heavy.
data.author: Barrett Allen

data.text: definitely balance the weight out .. I know what you mean about wheeling üòÇüòÇ
data.author: Debs Phil Walton Smith

data.text: Yea, I thought that this may be an issue also, reason why I went for another pannier(as I already had one), so I could balance the weights on the left and right on the rack. I will still have a handle bar large bag, and also a large stem bag, so hopefully things won't be to over balanced, fingers crossed :)
data.author: Ray Breen

data.text: live and learn eh... I'm just glad I made it home üòÇ a few times it happened when crossing roads which was sketchy
data.author: Barrett Allen

data.text: balance is the main thing for sure. If you're unevenly balanced you could easily crash which could be disastrous depending on where etc. Enjoy it though üëç the weather is getting good so evening temperature should allow you to pack a bit lighter
data.author: Barrett Allen

data.text: Yea, not decided on clothes yet, but may just bring something light and casual to wear for when i am off the bike and if needed overnight in my sleeping bag if it's too cold in just my boxers, as I want to see how I can handle the cold/heat.
data.author: Ray Breen

data.text: omg! Dont mention cross roads üòÇ. Stopped at one last week in liverpool and a car pulled up and 4 lads jumped out and attacked a young lad walking right in front of me. Nothing to do with balancing weight but will always remember it.
data.author: Debs Phil Walton Smith

data.text: Jeez, thats a bit mad. I used to live in liverpool in the 80's(wavertree and anfield) and it was a bit dodgy then, dread to think what its like now
data.author: Ray Breen

data.text: it was in Anfield ..
data.author: Debs Phil Walton Smith

data.text: A chair is a good thing to take.
data.author: Steve Lindley

data.text:
Yea, thats what i thought, but its rarely mentioned on the bike packing or backpacking crowd. Here is the seat i have got --> https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B07RTGHLNV/ref=pe_27063361_487055811_TE_dp_1?th=1 and the table --> https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B083ZDNNKL/ref=pe_27063361_485629781_TE_item
Naturehike Portable Camping Chair Ultra Light Folding Chair, Quick Disassembly and Assembly,for Fishing,Picnic,Outdoor,Hiking (Black)
amazon.co.uk
data.author: Ray Breen

data.text: Need a second power bank ü™´
data.author: Nick Burrill

data.text: Yea, i will be bringing a fully charged power bank, which i will use to keep my head unit and phone topped up. I will connect the power bank to a 15w solar panel, so, hopefully with the weather at the moment, the power bank will be kept charged up give or take on the ride, but will also have it attached to the panel when i pitch my tent.
data.author: Ray Breen

data.text: Carry a spare bank card in a different bag.
data.author: Andrew Bucknall

data.text: good idea, thanks!
data.author: Ray Breen

data.text: I learnt the hard way. Left my backpack at a rest stop in Plymouth and cycled up to Dartmoor. Cash, cards, power bank, other important stuff gone. Luckily I had friends in Plymouth who lent me cash and I obtained a bank card to use... (Don't ask it wasn't mine). I was bikepacking Land's End to Leicestershire. Not an ideal scenario.
data.author: Andrew Bucknall

data.text: Oh no, that is not good. I am planning to bring two phones with me, one for the komoot live tracking/guidance(as it has a decent battery, so it will last all day easily, as well as my head unit) and my main phone(Samsung fold 3, on which the battery sucks). I wasnt planning to put google pay on my bike phone, that way if it goes lost, nothing major to worry about, but may do so now, so at least I have a backup payment method.
data.author: Ray Breen

data.text: happened because by this point I was hungry after not being able to eat enough for past few days. See my other comments on your post. Fatigue/hunger causes lack of concentration and mistakes.
data.author: Andrew Bucknall

data.text: Regardless of where you are and what the weather forecast says, carry a waterproof jacket. Take a charger plug and lead with you and whenever you go inside somewhere make hunting down a socket priority number one.
data.author: Brian Debdencycle Lindsell

data.text: Haha yes, i have a small packaway waterproof, its not perfect, but does the job. Good idea about a charger, will add that to my list
data.author: Ray Breen

data.text: Just enjoy the whole experience. You‚Äôll fine what works for you, what you didn‚Äôt need to take and what you missed, travel at party pace and take in your surroundings. Stop to take a pic or two, have a coffee and try to leave a little time at the end of each day to chill and relax. Have a fab time mate‚Ä¶
data.author: Shaun Phillips

data.text: Thanks bud, all great words of advice :)
data.author: Ray Breen

data.text: I take a chair too! Beats sitting on the damp grass‚Ä¶
data.author: Shaun Phillips

data.text: Yea üôÇ and much easier to cook and eat
data.author: Ray Breen

data.text: I fitted a kick stand as it‚Äôs a pain lifting up a fully loaded bike and it‚Äôs easier to fit the panniers
data.author: Nick Tracey

data.text: THanks, got one already on this bike, as i hate lying it on the ground, as you are not always near grass
data.author: Ray Breen

data.text: You'll figure it out. Over the 20+ years I've been doing it, the kit has been gradually refined into what works for me - but it won't necessarily work for others; you can only do it by trial and error. I've ditched some things (e.g., a tarp), but added a few - a larger tent, a kettle, a piece of foam to sit on in the camp, windshield for the stove; figured out how much gas I need, what to pack in the tool bag, which panniers are best for me etc. I actually quite enjoy this process.
data.author: Pavel Bogolyubov

data.text: Hi , i have most of the items on your list, got a 2 man tent(naturehike start river 2), xl sleeping bag, no kettle, but will just boil the water in my cheapo camping set atm. Yea, i have enjoyed the research, as thats the interesting part, now gotta put it into practice :)
data.author: Ray Breen

data.text: The camping set I have is two pots and a kettle, plus a lid. Just simple aluminium, and cost me about a tenner 10 years ago, although it's something like Outwell. And you know what; I'll keep using it, although I do also have a Jetboil system for about a hundred quid. Cheap doesn't mean bad - the expense often comes from lightweighting or making it compact, and that's not always a priority. Although I did splash out on a titanium spork from PalnetX recently. It was three quid on sale lol :)
data.author: Pavel Bogolyubov

data.text: haha, yes, i have the same kit, the outwell one, with the little pocket rocket rip off üôÇ Yes, the jetboil look good, but are very expensive and limiting(without spending more money on compatible kit)
data.author: Ray Breen

data.text: I always take a chair. I have a dodgy back and the ability to give it a bit of a rest in the evening is well worth the marginal weight penalty. I would say though that a table is overkill.
data.author: Iain Christie

data.text: Yea, i am in two minds about the table, but will see how it works out, could turn out to be more of a hindarance then a benefit, only time will tell :)
data.author: Ray Breen

data.text: I feel the same re packing too muchüôÇ but then I look at some people's set up and think I haven't packed enoughüòÅ
data.author: Douglas Woodhouse

data.text: haha yea, as said, everyone has their own priorites , wants and needs. I have been cherry picking items and kit from the various youtube videos I have watched, same from this forum
data.author: Ray Breen

data.text: I saw a video on tube and it advised just one luxury! I chose an electric razorüôÇ
data.author: Douglas Woodhouse

data.text: haha, I have not thought at all about that, My facial hair grows at an exceptional rate. If I did not shave for a few days, i would look like Boris Karloff's rendition of the wolf man(not quite, but you get my point hehe) On that point though, i have not though much about toiletries, and a towel. Seeing as the place i am going to has showers, I need something..
data.author: Ray Breen

data.text: I'm taking a micro towel and a bar of soap üôÇ I spent a number of years in the forces so shaving with cold water out in the field was the norm..... enough is enoughü§£
data.author: Douglas Woodhouse

data.text: Yea, nearly went down another rabbit hole there, checking out travel toiletry kits on amazon lol. i stay at hotels on a semi regular basis and normally take home the small shower/toiletries that you are given. So will just take some of them.
data.author: Ray Breen

data.text: yep me to! ü§£üëçüôÇ
data.author: Douglas Woodhouse

data.text: I take packs of leaves of shave foam & soap, about to use shampoo leaves also. From millets
data.author: Geoff Morgan

data.text: sounds interesting might give it a go on my next tripüôÇüëç
data.author: Douglas Woodhouse

data.text: I came to bikepacking from running, where I would do over night runs. This meant I was already very minimalist but conversely I'm learning to add more home comforts. We can be too stripped back.
data.author: Mike French

data.text: We packed super light for a one month off road jaunt. But I advise you not to go overboard. I chopped my toothbrush in half to save weight and then got nerve damage in my hands and couldn‚Äôt brush my teeth üòÇ
data.author: Ffinlo Kilner

data.text: oh no, thats not good is it. i will take a travel toothbrush, a few extra grams(or pounds in my case) is not that much of a concern in the grand scheme of things, but then i am not doing a month's tour.
data.author: Ray Breen

data.text: Try a camping foldable toothbrush.
data.author: Andrew Weaver

data.text: Doesn‚Äôt change the weight. Just the size. Which wasn‚Äôt the problem! üòä
data.author: Ffinlo Kilner

data.text: Get a tubeless setup for your tyres. Punctures are no fun!
data.author: Carli Van

data.text: Don‚Äôt take too much shit. Heavy bikes are hard to ride and ruin the whole thing.
data.author: Morgan Jones

data.text: Ensure the bike is well greased and 100% before going, bikepacking pushes it to the limit, especially if gravel is involved. Peace of mind is everything on these trips.
data.author: George Julian Whitmarsh Hands

data.text: I was too cold in an ultralight sleeping bag and simple inflatable mattress. I now have an Alpkit Dirtbag mat, AK Pipedream 400 bag, AK Mantua silk liner and AK Drift pillow. IMHO the absolute success/failure of a trip is sleep quality. Wake up rested after a good night and you can churn the miles out, enjoy it, and deal with problems with a clear, positive head. Going cycling after crap sleep is just miserable.
data.author: Iain Christie

data.text: yea, thats so true. I have bought semi decent kit for my sleeping needs, like an xl sleeping bag, and a decent mat(TREKOLOGY UL) and a foil mat as a backup and lastly a sleeping bag liner and a decent pillow. If i end up doing any camping in the colder conditions, may get a tarp to wrap the sleeping bag in. heard that works wonders
data.author: Ray Breen

data.text: definitely need a decent insulated mat. I naively thought ‚Äúsurely air is quite insulating anyway‚Äù and tried out a cheap uninsulated mat in about minus 2. Luckily I was testing it in my garden so by 3am I was back in bed and by 9am I was looking for a proper mat!
data.author: Rob Kingston

data.text: ah yea,I can imagine that wasnt overly comfortable, at least you were not far from your bed üôÇ unfortunately my garden is flagged, so am unable to test the tent out there, but could do so at my parents.
data.author: Ray Breen

data.text: Ditch the chair & table, take a small piece of tarp to sit on. You don't need a table.
data.author: Andrew Weaver

data.text: I learnt that signposts on the NCN are not enough to navigate by. Get a gps or a map!
data.author: Sam Roberson

data.text: Hello everyone What‚Äôs a really warm but lightweight sleeping bag ?!
data.author: Cornelius Battanburg
